ground_truth: Brett still can't speak, and Jules savagely tips the card table over, removing the barrier between himself and Brett, who now sits like a political prisoner in front of an interrogator. Jules takes his .45 and presses the barrel hard into Brett's cheek as Brett regresses on the spot. Jules' eyes go to Vincent, who smirks, leading Jules to roll his eyes and shoot Brett in the shoulder. The two men then empty their guns at the same time on the sitting Brett. We fade up on Butch Coolidge, a white, 26-year-old prizefighter, who sits at a table wearing a red and blue high school athletic jacket. Talking to him off-screen is everybody's boss, Marsellus Wallace. A hand lays an envelope full of money on the table in front of Butch, who picks it up. Vincent Vega looks really cool behind the wheel of a 1964 cherry red Chevy Malibu convertible. The front entrance is unlocked, revealing the Dapper Dan fellow inside: English Dave. Vincent, carrying the black briefcase from the scene with Jules, steps inside, and English Dave slams the door in our faces. The spacious club is empty this time of day as English Dave crosses to the bar with Vince following. Butch shakes hands with a huge figure with his back to us, the infamous and as of yet still unseen Marsellus. English Dave smiles to himself and puts Vince's coffee in front of him. Butch does a slow turn toward Vincent, and as he turns his body, Vincent walks forward out of frame, never giving Butch another glance, before hugging and kissing the obscured figure that is Marsellus. Butch wisely decides that since this asshole is a friend of Marsellus, he better let it go for now and is snapped out of his ass-kicking thoughts. He pays English Dave and walks out of the shot. A woman who seems to have a fondness for earrings, with both ears pierced five times, and rings in her lips, eyebrows, and nose, is seen. Jody, Vincent, and a young woman named Trudi sit at the kitchen table of a suburban house in Echo Park. Vince has been letting the conversation go through one ear and out the other until the last remark catches his attention. Jody looks at him and states something as if it were the most obvious thing in the world, then continues talking to Trudi, leaving Vincent to ponder the truth of her statement. Vincent takes out a roll of money large enough to choke a horse to death and his case of works (utensils for shooting up) as he cooks his heroin.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Brett remains unable to utter a single word, and in a sudden, aggressive motion, Jules violently tips over the card table, effectively removing the physical barrier that had been separating him from Brett. Now, Brett sits vulnerably, much like a political prisoner facing an intense interrogation. Jules, with a determined expression, takes his .45 caliber gun and forcefully presses the cold barrel against Brett's cheek, causing Brett to visibly regress in fear right on the spot. Jules then shifts his gaze towards Vincent, who responds with a smirk, prompting Jules to roll his eyes in exasperation before shooting Brett in the shoulder. In a synchronized action, both men empty their guns simultaneously on the seated Brett. 

The scene transitions, and we find ourselves focusing on Butch Coolidge, a 26-year-old prizefighter of Caucasian descent, who is seated at a table. He is wearing a red and blue high school athletic jacket, which adds a touch of nostalgia to his appearance. Engaging him in conversation from off-screen is the formidable figure known as Marsellus Wallace, who is the boss of everyone around. A hand, belonging to an unseen individual, places an envelope filled with money on the table in front of Butch, who promptly picks it up. Meanwhile, Vincent Vega exudes an air of effortless coolness as he sits behind the wheel of a 1964 cherry red Chevy Malibu convertible. The front entrance swings open, revealing the dapper figure of English Dave inside. Vincent, carrying the iconic black briefcase from the earlier scene with Jules, steps inside, and English Dave promptly slams the door shut in our faces.

The spacious club is notably empty at this time of day, creating an almost eerie atmosphere as English Dave makes his way to the bar, with Vince following closely behind. Butch extends his hand to shake with a massive figure whose back is turned to us, the infamous and still unseen Marsellus. English Dave, with a knowing smile, places Vince's coffee in front of him. Butch slowly turns his attention toward Vincent, and as he does so, Vincent strides forward, moving out of frame without sparing Butch another glance. He then embraces and kisses the obscured figure of Marsellus. Butch, realizing the wisdom in not provoking someone who is clearly a friend of Marsellus, decides to let go of his thoughts of confrontation for the moment. He is abruptly snapped out of his ass-kicking thoughts, pays English Dave, and exits the scene.

A woman with a noticeable fondness for earrings is observed, her ears pierced five times each, and rings adorning her lips, eyebrows, and nose. This is Jody, who, along with Vincent and a young woman named Trudi, sits at the kitchen table of a suburban house located in Echo Park. Vincent has been largely ignoring the conversation, letting it pass through one ear and out the other, until a particular remark catches his attention. Jody looks at him and makes a statement as if it were the most obvious thing in the world, then continues her conversation with Trudi, leaving Vincent to ponder the truth of her words. Vincent then takes out a roll of money so large it could choke a horse to death, along with his case of works, which are utensils for shooting up, as he prepares to cook his heroin.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Brett finds himself utterly incapable of speaking a single word at this moment. In a sudden, aggressive, and forceful motion, Jules violently upends the card table, decisively removing the physical barrier that had stood between him and Brett, symbolically eliminating any distance between them. Now, Brett finds himself sitting vulnerably and defenseless, much like a political prisoner facing the intense pressure of a severe interrogation. Jules, with a determined and resolute expression on his face, retrieves his .45 caliber gun and forcefully presses the cold, unyielding barrel against Brett's cheek, causing Brett to visibly shrink back in fear and terror right on the spot. Jules then shifts his gaze towards Vincent, who responds with a smirk, which prompts Jules to roll his eyes in exasperation before he proceeds to shoot Brett in the shoulder. In perfect synchronization, both men empty their guns in a hail of bullets, simultaneously, on the seated and helpless Brett.

The scene transitions smoothly and seamlessly, taking us to a different focus altogether. We find ourselves turning our attention to Butch Coolidge, a 26-year-old prizefighter of Caucasian descent. He is seen seated at a table, wearing a red and blue high school athletic jacket, which adds a nostalgic touch to his overall appearance. A hand, belonging to an unseen individual, deliberately places an envelope filled with money on the table right in front of Butch, who promptly picks it up without hesitation. Meanwhile, Vincent Vega exudes an undeniable air of effortless coolness as he sits behind the wheel of a 1964 cherry red Chevy Malibu convertible. The front entrance swings open, revealing the dapper and well-dressed figure of English Dave inside. Vincent, carrying the iconic black briefcase from the earlier scene with Jules, steps inside, and just as quickly, English Dave promptly slams the door shut in our faces, leaving an air of mystery.

The spacious club appears notably empty at this time of day, creating an almost eerie and ghostly atmosphere as English Dave makes his way casually to the bar, with Vince following closely behind him. Butch reaches out and extends his hand to shake with a massive figure whose back is turned to us, the infamous and still unseen Marsellus. English Dave, wearing a knowing smile, places Vince's coffee in front of him with a certain familiarity. Butch slowly turns his attention toward Vincent, and as he does so, Vincent confidently strides forward, moving out of the frame without sparing Butch another glance. He then goes on to embrace and kiss the obscured figure of Marsellus. Butch, realizing the wisdom in not provoking someone who is clearly a close friend of Marsellus, decides to let go of his thoughts of confrontation, at least for the moment. He is abruptly snapped out of his ass-kicking thoughts, pays English Dave for the service, and exits the scene.

A woman with a noticeable fondness for earrings captures attention, her ears pierced five times each, with rings adorning her lips, eyebrows, and nose. This is Jody, who, along with Vincent and a young woman named Trudi, sits at the kitchen table of a suburban house located in Echo Park. Vincent has been largely disengaged from the conversation, letting it pass through one ear and out the other, until a particular remark catches his attention. Jody looks at him and makes a statement as if it were the most obvious thing in the world, then continues her conversation with Trudi, leaving Vincent to ponder deeply the truth of her words. Vincent then takes out a roll of money so large it could choke a horse to death, along with his case of works, which are utensils for shooting up, as he prepares to cook his heroin with focused intent.

Butch shakes hands with a huge figure with his back to us the infamous and as of yet still unseen Marsellus. English Dave smiles to himself and puts Vince's coffee in front of him. Butch does a slow turn toward Vincent and as he turns his body Vincent walks forward out of frame never giving Butch another glance before hugging and kissing the obscured figure that is Marsellus. Butch wisely decides that since this asshole is a friend of Marsellus he better let it go for now and is snapped out of his asskicking thoughts. He pays English Dave and walks out of the shot. A woman who seems to have a fondness for earrings with both ears pierced five times and rings in her lips eyebrows and nose is seen. Jody Vincent and a young woman named Trudi sit at the kitchen table of a suburban house in Echo Park. Vince has been letting the conversation go through one ear and out the other until the last remark catches his attention. Jody looks at him and states something as if it were the most obvious thing in the world. then continues talking to Trudi leaving Vincent to ponder the truth of her statement. Vincent takes out a roll of money large enough to choke a horse to death and his case of works utensils for shooting up as he cooks his heroin.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Brett still cannot speak and Jules savagely tips the card table over removing the barrier between himself and Brett who now sits like a political prisoner in front of an interrogator. Jules takes his 45 and presses the barrel hard into Brett's cheek. as Brett regresses on the spot Jules' eyes go to Vincent who smirks leading Jules to roll his eyes and shoot Brett in the shoulder. The two men then empty their guns at the same time on the sitting Brett. We fade up on Butch Coolidge a white 26yearold prizefighter who sits at a table wearing a red and blue high school athletic jacket. Talking to him offscreen is everybody's boss Marsellus Wallace. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gary still can't draw, and Linda delicately flips the bicycle rack over, dismantling the wall between herself and Gary, who now stands like a famous author in front of an eager audience. Linda grabs her book and places the cover gently against Gary's chin as Gary laughs on the spot. Linda's gaze wanders to Helen, who chuckles, prompting Linda to sigh and paint Gary's shoulder. The two artists then fill their palettes simultaneously over the standing Gary. We fade up on Mandy Greenway, a blonde, 23-year-old carpenter, who stands at a counter wearing a green and yellow college varsity sweater. Conversing off-screen is everyone's friend, Lorenzo Adams. A hand places a folder full of sketches on the counter in front of Mandy, who examines it. Helen Baker looks incredibly relaxed behind the wheel of a 1972 lime green Ford Mustang convertible. The side gate swings open, revealing the Stylish Steve fellow inside: Australian Harry. Helen, carrying the brown suitcase from the scene with Linda, steps inside, and Australian Harry shuts the door in our faces. The expansive studio is empty this time of day as Australian Harry moves to the easel with Helen trailing. Mandy shakes hands with a massive figure with her back to us, the renowned and as of yet still unseen Lorenzo. Australian Harry grins to himself and places Helen's tea in front of her. Mandy makes a gentle turn toward Helen, and as she pivots her stance, Helen strides forward out of view, never acknowledging Mandy again, before embracing and greeting the concealed figure that is Lorenzo. Mandy wisely concludes that since this jester is an ally of Lorenzo, she better ignore it for now and is jolted out of her inventing thoughts. She compensates Australian Harry and exits the scene. A gentleman who seems to have an affinity for shoes, with both feet adorned five times, and studs in his ears, nostrils, and lips, is observed. Cody, Helen, and an elderly man named Oscar sit at the dining table of a city apartment in Echo Bay. Helen has been letting the banter meander through one ear and out the other until the final comment captures her attention. Cody glances at her and proposes something as if it were the most evident thing imaginable, then resumes chatting with Oscar, leaving Helen to contemplate the reality of his assertion. Helen pulls out a collection of keys large enough to fill a piggy bank to the brim and her case of tools (instruments for crafting) as she assembles her creation.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Brett, unable to speak, sits like a prisoner as Jules aggressively tips the table and presses a gun to Brett's cheek, signaling dominance. After a shared glance with Vincent, Jules shoots Brett in the shoulder before both men unload their guns on him. The scene shifts to Butch Coolidge, a 26-year-old prizefighter, who receives an envelope of cash from Marsellus Wallace, their boss. Vincent Vega drives a cherry red Chevy Malibu to meet English Dave at a club. Butch encounters Marsellus, realizing he shouldn’t confront Vincent since they’re friends. Meanwhile, in Echo Park, Jody, with numerous piercings, converses with Trudi and Vincent. Vincent, distracted by their discussion, is caught pondering a statement from Jody before proceeding to prepare heroin.
